column2: To make ashamed or uneasy; disconcert. See Synonyms at embarrass.
A slaughterhouse.
To relinquish (power or responsibility) formally.
The condition of being temporarily set aside; suspension:  held the plan in abeyance.
Brought low in condition or status. See Synonyms at mean2.
Self-denial.
Eating and drinking in moderation.
Bitter and sharp in language or tone; rancorous:  an acrimonious debate between the two candidates.
Bitter, sharp animosity, especially as exhibited in speech or behavior.
To reprove gently but earnestly.
Cheerful willingness; eagerness.
One who is employed to take dictation or to copy manuscript.
The coexistence of opposing attitudes or feelings, such as love and hate, toward a person, object, or idea.
Friendly and agreeable in disposition; good-natured and likable.
Characterized by or exhibiting friendliness or goodwill; friendly.
Strongly attracted or disposed to love, especially sexual love.
Having no defined shape, lacking form; amorphous.
Erroneous in date; containing an anachronism; in a wrong time.
Relating to, having, or producing different optical imaging effects along mutually perpendicular radii:  an anamorphic lens.
Having the form of a man
To ascribe human characteristics to.
Self-confident assurance; poise. See Synonyms at confidence.
A person who renounces material comforts and leads a life of austere self-discipline, especially as an act of religious devotion.
The principles and practices of an ascetic; extreme self-denial and austerity.
Plural form of aspersion.
To agree, as to a proposal; concur.
Constant in application or attention; diligent:  an assiduous worker who strove for perfection.  See Synonyms at busy.
To make (something burdensome or painful) less intense or severe:  assuage her grief.  See Synonyms at relieve.
Pathology   A wasting or decrease in size of a body organ, tissue, or part owing to disease, injury, or lack of use:  muscular atrophy of a person affected with paralysis.
Plural of auspex.
The quality of being austere.
Immoderate desire for wealth; cupidity.
Showing or producing exalted joy or blessedness:  a beatific smile.
To deceive by guile; delude. See Synonyms at deceive.
Favorable; beneficial.
Suffering the loss of a loved one:  the bereaved family.
A past tense and a past participle of bereave.
To make a hole in or through, with or as if with a drill.
A false statement maliciously made to injure another's reputation.
Characterized by or subject to whim; impulsive and unpredictable. See Synonyms at arbitrary.
To find fault unnecessarily; raise trivial objections. See Synonyms at quibble.
An expression of strong disapproval or harsh criticism.
A keen feeling of mental unease, as of annoyance or embarrassment, caused by failure, disappointment, or a disconcerting event:  To her chagrin, the party ended just as she arrived.
Of, like, or befitting a churl; boorish or vulgar.
Heedful of circumstances and potential consequences; prudent.
A disposition to show mercy, especially toward an offender or enemy. See Synonyms at mercy.

A punishment or retribution that one deserves; one's just deserts: "It's a chance to strike back at the critical brotherhood and give each his comeuppance for evaluative sins of the past”  ( Judith Crist).
A strong uneasiness caused by a sense of guilt. See Synonyms at penitence.
To suggest or imply in addition to literal meaning: "The term 'liberal arts' connotes a certain elevation above utilitarian concerns”  ( George F. Will).  See Usage Note at denote.
A woman who makes teasing sexual or romantic overtures; a flirt.
Excessive desire, especially for wealth; covetousness or avarice.
A curious or unusual object of art or piece of bric-a-brac.
A scarce supply; a lack: "the dearth of uncensored, firsthand information about the war”  ( Richard Zoglin).
To mark; indicate:  a frown that denoted increasing impatience.
To feel or express strong disapproval of; condemn: "Somehow we had to master events, not simply deplore them”  ( Henry A. Kissinger).
in a mocking and demeaning manner.
To catch sight of (something difficult to discern). See Synonyms at see1.
directly opposite
Intended to instruct.
Lacking or marked by a lack of self-confidence; shy and timid. See Synonyms at shy1.
Intended to delay.
Covering a wide field of subjects; rambling.
One's usual mood; temperament:  a sweet disposition.
Stubbornly persevering; tenacious. See Synonyms at obstinate.
To express oneself dogmatically in writing or speech.
A collection of papers giving detailed information about a particular person or subject.
To show excessive fondness or love:  parents who dote on their only child.
To slobber; drool.
Deliberate deceptiveness in behavior or speech.
A decree or proclamation issued by an authority and having the force of law.
Giving off bubbles; fizzy.
Power or capacity to produce a desired effect; effectiveness.
Unrestrained or excessive in emotional expression; gushy:  an effusive manner.
The art of public speaking in which gesture, vocal production, and delivery are emphasized.
The act or an instance of emanating.
Listlessness and dissatisfaction resulting from lack of interest; boredom: "The servants relieved their ennui with gambling and gossip about their masters”  ( John Barth).
To settle (oneself) securely or comfortably:  She ensconced herself in an armchair.
Lasting for a markedly brief time: "There remain some truths too ephemeral to be captured in the cold pages of a court transcript”  ( Irving R. Kaufman).
A person with refined taste, especially in food and wine.
A term used to characterize a person or thing, such as rosy-fingered in rosy-fingered dawn or the Great in Catherine the Great.
Roving, especially in search of adventure:  knights errant.
To show or demonstrate clearly; manifest:  evince distaste by grimacing.
To tear or wear off the skin of; abrade. See Synonyms at chafe.
Deserving of execration; hateful.
To declare to be hateful or abhorrent; denounce.
To reason earnestly with someone in an effort to dissuade or correct; remonstrate. See Synonyms at object.
To do or perform (something) without prior preparation or practice:  extemporized an acceptance speech.
To rejoice greatly; be jubilant or triumphant.
Conspicuously bad, offensive, or reprehensible:  a flagrant miscarriage of justice; flagrant cases of wrongdoing at the highest levels of government.  See Usage Note at blatant.
To pass off as genuine, valuable, or worthy: "I can usually tell whether a poet . . . is foisting off on us what he'd like to think is pure invention”  ( J.D. Salinger).
To leap about playfully; frolic.
Marked by strident color or excessive ornamentation; gaudy.
Of or relating to geriatrics.
Treacherous cunning; skillful deceit.
A long pompous speech, especially one delivered before a gathering.
A diminutive human.
The condition of being a huckster
Not noble in quality, character, or purpose; base or mean. See Synonyms at mean2.
Marked by shame or disgrace: "It was an ignominious end ... as a desperate mutiny by a handful of soldiers blossomed into full-scale revolt”  ( Angus Deming).
Great personal dishonor or humiliation.
Exceeding the limits of propriety or good manners; improperly forward or bold:  impertinent of a child to lecture a grownup.
The quality or condition of being impetuous.
Characterized by sudden and forceful energy or emotion; impulsive and passionate.
The quality of being offensively bold.
To attack as false or questionable; challenge in argument:  impugn a political opponent's record.
Exemption from punishment, penalty, or harm.
Not favorable; not auspicious.
Continuing without interruption. See Synonyms at continual.
Penetrating, clear, and sharp, as in operation or expression:  an incisive mind; incisive comments.
Incapable of being corrected or reformed:  an incorrigible criminal.
The state or quality of being incredulous; disbelief.
Skeptical; disbelieving:  incredulous of stories about flying saucers.
Lacking propriety or good taste. See Synonyms at improper.
Incapable or seemingly incapable of being fatigued; tireless. See Synonyms at tireless.
Impossible to remove, erase, or wash away; permanent:  indelible ink.
To protect against damage, loss, or injury; insure.
Anger aroused by something unjust, mean, or unworthy. See Synonyms at anger.
So intricate or entangled as to make escape impossible:  an inextricable maze; an inextricable web of deceit.
A bodily ailment or weakness, especially one brought on by old age.
Injurious or harmful in effect; adverse:  habits inimical to good health.
Gross immorality or injustice; wickedness.
Difficult to fathom or understand; impenetrable. See Synonyms at mysterious.
Lacking flavor or zest; not tasty.
Presumptuous and insulting in manner or speech; arrogant.
Resolutely courageous; fearless. See Synonyms at brave.
Firmly and long established; deep-rooted:  inveterate preferences.
Lacking or exhibiting a lack of reverence; disrespectful.
Fate; fortune.
Lacking brightness, luster, or vitality; dull. See Synonyms at dull.
Using or marked by the use of few words; terse or concise. See Synonyms at silent.
To be or become weak or feeble; lose strength or vigor.
lacking energy, spirit, liveliness or vitality; languid, lackadaisical
Given to or expressing lust; lecherous.
Deserving commendation; praiseworthy.
The state or quality of being lax.
Lightness of manner or speech, especially when inappropriate; frivolity.
A prescribed form or set of forms for public religious worship.
Very talkative; garrulous.
The act of plotting.
To rove and raid in search of plunder.
Reincarnation.
Gladness and gaiety, especially when expressed by laughter.
To toil; slave.
A person who is obsessed with a single thing, to the exclusion of other concerns.
Bitingly sarcastic:  mordant satire.
Coming into existence; emerging: "the moral shock of our nascent imperialism”  ( Richard Hofstadter).
Of, resembling, relating to, or consisting of a name or names.
Bewildered; unsure how to respond or act.
Abusively detractive language or utterance; calumny: "I have had enough obloquy for one lifetime”  ( Anthony Eden).
Full of or exhibiting servile compliance; fawning.
Stubbornly adhering to an attitude, opinion, or course of action; obdurate.
Arousing or meriting strong dislike, aversion, or intense displeasure. See Synonyms at hateful.
Mean-spirited, disagreeable, and contrary in disposition; cantankerous.
Of ideas or attitudes, inflexible, old-fashioned.
seemingly, apparently, on the surface
Having an abnormally pale or wan complexion:  the pallid face of the invalid.
A remedy for all diseases, evils, or difficulties; a cure-all.
Dash; verve.
A model of excellence or perfection of a kind; a peerless example:  a paragon of virtue.
A definite liking; a strong inclination. See Synonyms at predilection.
Of, relating to, or marked by perfidy; treacherous. See Synonyms at faithless.
Tending to cause death or serious injury; deadly:  a pernicious virus.
Acuteness of perception, discernment, or understanding.
The quality or state of being perverse.
The distinctive scent which accompanies the first rain after a long warm dry spell.
Unreasonably irritable or ill-tempered; peevish.
A compact or close-knit body of people: "formed a solid phalanx in defense of the Constitution and Protestant religion”  ( G.M. Trevelyan).
A love potion.
Precisely meaningful; forceful and brief:  a pithy comment.
The use of more words than are required to express an idea; redundancy.
Profoundly moving; touching:  a poignant memory.  See Synonyms at moving.
Having great weight.
The office or term of office of a pontiff.
To serve as an omen or a warning of; presage:  black clouds that portend a storm.
Of the nature of or constituting a portent; foreboding: "The present aspect of society is portentous of great change”  ( Edward Bellamy).
Occurring or continuing after one's death:  a posthumous award.
To throw from or as if from a great height; hurl downward: "The finest bridge in all Peru broke and precipitated five travelers into the gulf below”  ( Thornton Wilder).
Manifesting or characterized by unusually early development or maturity, especially in mental aptitude.
A partiality or disposition in favor of something; a preference.
Plural form of privation.
Complete and confirmed integrity; uprightness: "He was a gentlemanly Georgian, a person of early American probity”  ( Mary McGrory).
Plural form of proclivity.
Rashly or wastefully extravagant:  prodigal expenditures on unneeded weaponry; a prodigal life.
Impressively great in size, force, or extent; enormous:  a prodigious storm.
Careless wastefulness.
Tediously prolonged; wordy:  editing a prolix manuscript.
To make known (a decree, for example) by public declaration; announce officially. See Synonyms at announce.
An innate inclination; a tendency. See Synonyms at predilection.
An elevated platform, lectern, or stand used in preaching or conducting a religious service.
Of, relating to, or having the nature of a quintessence; being the most typical: "Liszt was the quintessential romantic”  ( Musical Heritage Review).
Caught up in the romance of noble deeds and the pursuit of unreachable goals; idealistic without regard to practicality.
Everyday; commonplace: "There's nothing quite like a real . . . train conductor to add color to a quotidian commute”  ( Anita Diamant).
To have complicating consequences or outgrowths:  The problem merely ramified after the unsuccessful meeting.
Taking by force; plundering.
A blunt or abrupt repulse or refusal, as to an offer.
Not easily understood; abstruse. See Synonyms at ambiguous.
Shining radiantly; resplendent.
To say or plead in protest, objection, or reproof.
Retaliation for an injury with the intent of inflicting at least as much injury in return.
Firm or determined; unwavering.
Splendid or dazzling in appearance; brilliant.
Relating to laughter or used in eliciting laughter.
A memorizing process using routine or repetition, often without full attention or comprehension:  learn by rote.
To wander about at random, especially over a wide area; roam.
To turn a matter over and over in the mind.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of sugar or saccharin; sweet.
Having or showing keen discernment, sound judgment, and farsightedness. See Synonyms at shrewd.
In a sardonic manner; cynically; mockingly; scornfully; sarcastically.
Present participle of scintillate.
Inducing or tending to induce sleep.
Filthy or dirty; foul.
Having the ring of truth or plausibility but actually fallacious:  a specious argument.
To render useless or ineffectual; cripple.
A deceptive stratagem or device: "the paltry subterfuge of an anonymous signature”  ( Robert Smith Surtees).
To break or wrench apart; sever. See Synonyms at separate.
Of the highest order, quality, or degree; surpassing or superior to all others.
Readily bent; pliant.
Foolhardy disregard of danger; recklessness.
The four-dimensional equivalent of a cube.
Of or relating to barbering or a barber.
Deprived of the power of motion or feeling; benumbed.
Existing or extending beyond the physical world.
Forceful, effective, and vigorous:  a trenchant argument.  See Synonyms at incisive.
A state of alarm or dread; apprehension. See Synonyms at fear.
The capacity or activity of a guardian; guardianship.
To serve as a typical example of; embody the essential characteristics of:  a painting that typifies the artist's work.
Lying beyond what is evident, revealed, or avowed, especially being concealed intentionally so as to deceive:  an ulterior motive.
Being such that defense or maintenance is impossible:  an untenable position.
Not favorable; unpropitious.
The practice of lending money and charging the borrower interest, especially at an exorbitant or illegally high rate.
Of or characteristic of a prophet; oracular.
Volition at its lowest level.
Open to bribery; mercenary:  a venal police officer.
Commanding respect by virtue of age, dignity, character, or position.
Adherence to the truth; truthfulness. See Synonyms at truth.
Plural form of vicissitude.
A woman regarded as noisy, scolding, or domineering.
Extremely infectious, malignant, or poisonous. Used of a disease or toxin.
The act or an instance of making a conscious choice or decision.
Having great volume, fullness, size, or number:  a voluminous trunk; a voluminous cloud.
To twist, as in pain, struggle, or embarrassment.
Enthusiastic devotion to a cause, ideal, or goal and tireless diligence in its furtherance. See Synonyms at passion.
